The Pharisees attached the shame of guilt to poverty and affliction; it was the punishment of God for secret or open sin, personal or inherited3 it was not sent in love but in anger. In opposition to this doctrine Jesus strongly insists on the blessedness of suffering, and, contrary to other Oriental teachers, his idea seems to have been that its chief use consisted in awakening desire. But it is also very plain from the whole course of his ministry that he con- sidered the discipline of joy every whit as needful.
